maml:description.maml:para: Adds a range of addresses to exclude from a multicast scope.

The Add-DhcpServerv4MulticastExclusionRange cmdlet add a range of addresses to exclude from a multicast scope. An exclusion prevents the Dynamic Host Configuration Protocol (DHCP) Server service from offering these addresses for DHCP assignment.
Specifies the name of the multicast scope for which to add the IP address exclusion range.
Specifies the low end of the range of IP addresses to exclude from a multicast scope.
Specifies the high end of the range of IP addresses to exclude from a multicast scope.

Runs the cmdlet as a background job. Use this parameter to run commands that take a long time to complete. The cmdlet immediately returns an object that represents the job and then displays the command prompt. You can continue to work in the session while the job completes. To manage the job, use the *-Job cmdlets. To get the job results, use the Receive-Job cmdlet. For more information about Windows PowerShell® background jobs, see about_Jobs.

Runs the cmdlet in a remote session or on a remote computer. Enter a computer name or a session object, such as the output of a New-CimSession or Get-CimSession cmdlet. The default is the current session on the local computer.
Specifies the Domain Name System (DNS) name or IP address of the target computer that runs the DHCP Server service.
Returns an object representing the item with which you are working. By default, this cmdlet does not generate any output.

Specifies the maximum number of concurrent operations that can be established to run the cmdlet. If this parameter is omitted or a value of 0 is entered, then Windows PowerShell® calculates an optimum throttle limit for the cmdlet based on the number of CIM cmdlets that are running on the computer. The throttle limit applies only to the current cmdlet, not to the session or to the computer.
Prompts you for confirmation before running the cmdlet.
Shows what would happen if the cmdlet runs. The cmdlet is not run.

Runs the cmdlet as a background job. Use this parameter to run commands that take a long time to complete. The cmdlet immediately returns an object that represents the job and then displays the command prompt. You can continue to work in the session while the job completes. To manage the job, use the *-Job cmdlets. To get the job results, use the Receive-Job cmdlet. For more information about Windows PowerShell® background jobs, see about_Jobs.

Runs the cmdlet in a remote session or on a remote computer. Enter a computer name or a session object, such as the output of a New-CimSession or Get-CimSession cmdlet. The default is the current session on the local computer.
Specifies the Domain Name System (DNS) name or IP address of the target computer that runs the DHCP Server service.
Specifies the high end of the range of IP addresses to exclude from a multicast scope.
Specifies the name of the multicast scope for which to add the IP address exclusion range.
Returns an object representing the item with which you are working. By default, this cmdlet does not generate any output.
Specifies the low end of the range of IP addresses to exclude from a multicast scope.

Specifies the maximum number of concurrent operations that can be established to run the cmdlet. If this parameter is omitted or a value of 0 is entered, then Windows PowerShell® calculates an optimum throttle limit for the cmdlet based on the number of CIM cmdlets that are running on the computer. The throttle limit applies only to the current cmdlet, not to the session or to the computer.
Prompts you for confirmation before running the cmdlet.
Shows what would happen if the cmdlet runs. The cmdlet is not run.

command:example.maml:title: Example 1: Add an exclusion range for a multicast scope

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command adds an exclusion range with the IP addresses 224.0.0.21 to 224.0.0.25 for the multicast scope named Multicast_AudioConferenceGroup on the DHCP Server service that runs on the computer named DhcpServer01.Contoso.com.

maml:description.maml:para: Retrieves the exclusion range for a specified multicast scope.

The Get-DhcpServerv4MulticastExclusionRange cmdlet retrieves the exclusion range for a specified multicast scope. An exclusion prevents the Dynamic Host Configuration Protocol (DHCP) Server service from offering these addresses for DHCP assignment.
Specifies an array of names of multicast scopes from which to remove an exclusion range.

Runs the cmdlet as a background job. Use this parameter to run commands that take a long time to complete. The cmdlet immediately returns an object that represents the job and then displays the command prompt. You can continue to work in the session while the job completes. To manage the job, use the *-Job cmdlets. To get the job results, use the Receive-Job cmdlet. For more information about Windows PowerShell® background jobs, see about_Jobs.

Runs the cmdlet in a remote session or on a remote computer. Enter a computer name or a session object, such as the output of a New-CimSession or Get-CimSession cmdlet. The default is the current session on the local computer.
Specifies the DNS name or IP address of the target computer that runs the DHCP Server service.

Specifies the maximum number of concurrent operations that can be established to run the cmdlet. If this parameter is omitted or a value of 0 is entered, then Windows PowerShell® calculates an optimum throttle limit for the cmdlet based on the number of CIM cmdlets that are running on the computer. The throttle limit applies only to the current cmdlet, not to the session or to the computer.

Runs the cmdlet as a background job. Use this parameter to run commands that take a long time to complete. The cmdlet immediately returns an object that represents the job and then displays the command prompt. You can continue to work in the session while the job completes. To manage the job, use the *-Job cmdlets. To get the job results, use the Receive-Job cmdlet. For more information about Windows PowerShell® background jobs, see about_Jobs.

Runs the cmdlet in a remote session or on a remote computer. Enter a computer name or a session object, such as the output of a New-CimSession or Get-CimSession cmdlet. The default is the current session on the local computer.
Specifies the DNS name or IP address of the target computer that runs the DHCP Server service.
Specifies an array of names of multicast scopes from which to remove an exclusion range.

Specifies the maximum number of concurrent operations that can be established to run the cmdlet. If this parameter is omitted or a value of 0 is entered, then Windows PowerShell® calculates an optimum throttle limit for the cmdlet based on the number of CIM cmdlets that are running on the computer. The throttle limit applies only to the current cmdlet, not to the session or to the computer.

command:example.maml:title: Example 1: Retrieve exclusion range for a scope

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command retrieves the exclusion ranges for the multicast scope Multicast_AudioConference.

command:example.maml:title: Example 2: Retrieve exclusion ranges for all multicast scopes

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command returns the exclusion ranges for all multicast scopes on the computer named DhcpServer01.Contoso.com.

maml:description.maml:para: Removes a range of addresses previously excluded from a multicast scope.

The Remove-DhcpServerv4MulticastExclusionRange cmdlet removes a range of addresses previously excluded from a multicast scope. The addresses are available immediately after the cmdlet runs. An exclusion prevents the Dynamic Host Configuration Protocol (DHCP) Server service from offering these addresses for DHCP assignment.
Specifies the name of the multicast scope from which to remove the IP address exclusion range.

Specifies the low end of the range of IP addresses that were previously excluded from the scope. Use the EndRange parameter to specify the high end of the range of IP addresses to remove from the exclusion range. If you do not specify the high end of the range by using the EndRange parameter, the cmdlet removes the exclusion range that begins with this parameter. If the DHCP Server service is not excluding addresses beginning at the specified value, the cmdlet returns an error and exits.
If you do not specify either the low end or the high end of the exclusion range, the cmdlet removes all exclusion ranges for the specified scope.

Specifies the high end of the range of IP addresses previously excluded from the scope. Use the StartRange parameter to specify the low end of the range of IP addresses to remove from the exclusion range. If you do not specify the low end of the range by using the StartRange parameter, the cmdlet removes the exclusion range that ends with this parameter. If the DHCP Server service is not excluding addresses ending at the specified value, the cmdlet returns an error and exits.
If you do not specify either the low end or the high end of the exclusion range, the cmdlet removes all exclusion ranges for the specified scope.

Runs the cmdlet as a background job. Use this parameter to run commands that take a long time to complete. The cmdlet immediately returns an object that represents the job and then displays the command prompt. You can continue to work in the session while the job completes. To manage the job, use the *-Job cmdlets. To get the job results, use the Receive-Job cmdlet. For more information about Windows PowerShell® background jobs, see about_Jobs.

Runs the cmdlet in a remote session or on a remote computer. Enter a computer name or a session object, such as the output of a New-CimSession or Get-CimSession cmdlet. The default is the current session on the local computer.
Specifies the Domain Name System (DNS) name or IP address of the target computer that runs the DHCP Server service.
Passthru If this parameter is specified, the cmdlet return the PowerShell objects which are deleted.

Specifies the maximum number of concurrent operations that can be established to run the cmdlet. If this parameter is omitted or a value of 0 is entered, then Windows PowerShell® calculates an optimum throttle limit for the cmdlet based on the number of CIM cmdlets that are running on the computer. The throttle limit applies only to the current cmdlet, not to the session or to the computer.
Prompts you for confirmation before running the cmdlet.
Shows what would happen if the cmdlet runs. The cmdlet is not run.

Runs the cmdlet as a background job. Use this parameter to run commands that take a long time to complete. To manage the job, use the *-Job cmdlets. To get the job results, use the Receive-Job cmdlet. For more information about Windows PowerShell® background jobs, see about_Jobs.

Specifies the Domain Name System (DNS) name or IP address of the target computer that runs the DHCP Server service.

Specifies the high end of the range of IP addresses previously excluded from the scope. Use the StartRange parameter to specify the low end of the range of IP addresses to remove from the exclusion range. If you do not specify the low end of the range by using the StartRange parameter, the cmdlet removes the exclusion range that ends with this parameter. If the DHCP Server service is not excluding addresses ending at the specified value, the cmdlet returns an error and exits.
If you do not specify either the low end or the high end of the exclusion range, the cmdlet removes all exclusion ranges for the specified scope.
Specifies the name of the multicast scope from which to remove the IP address exclusion range.
Passthru If this parameter is specified, the cmdlet return the PowerShell objects which are deleted.

Specifies the low end of the range of IP addresses that were previously excluded from the scope. Use the EndRange parameter to specify the high end of the range of IP addresses to remove from the exclusion range. If you do not specify the high end of the range by using the EndRange parameter, the cmdlet removes the exclusion range that begins with this parameter. If the DHCP Server service is not excluding addresses beginning at the specified value, the cmdlet returns an error and exits.
If you do not specify either the low end or the high end of the exclusion range, the cmdlet removes all exclusion ranges for the specified scope.

Specifies the maximum number of concurrent operations that can be established to run the cmdlet. If this parameter is omitted or a value of 0 is entered, then Windows PowerShell® calculates an optimum throttle limit for the cmdlet based on the number of CIM cmdlets that are running on the computer. The throttle limit applies only to the current cmdlet, not to the session or to the computer.
Prompts you for confirmation before running the cmdlet.
Shows what would happen if the cmdlet runs. The cmdlet is not run.

command:example.maml:title: Example 1: Remove an excluded address range by scope name

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command removes all excluded multicast IP address ranges from the multicast scope named Multicast_VideoConference from the DHCP Server service running on the computer named DhcpServer01.Contoso.com.

command:example.maml:title: Example 2: Remove an excluded address range by IP address

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command removes the excluded multicast IP address range 224.0.0.21 through 224.0.0.25 from the multicast scope named Multicast_VideoConference.

command:example.maml:title: Example 3: Remove an excluded address range by start range

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command removes the excluded multicast IP address range beginning with address 224.0.0.21. The command specifies the multicast scope named Multicast_VideoConference for the DHCP Server service running on the computer named DhcpServer01.Contoso.com.
